I think there is a bigger problem here, which far exceeds the triviality of 
reimagining Egypt through Caucasian actors and actresses. Hollywood, in 
most of their adaptations of the story of Moses, portrays the events that 
are depicted in the Book of Exodus as demonstrating the moral nobility of 
God and Moses. The truth is the story of Exodus is morally reprehensible. 
It essentially glorifies terrorism. After all, terrorism is the deliberate 
attempt to change the minds of governing authorities by targeting, 
torturing and murdering the innocent people who are the subjects of said 
government. God, visiting Egypt through plagues which poison the water, 
kill livestock, destroys farmland and kills the first born of all Egyptians 
- most of whom had nothing to do with the enslavement of the Israelites - 
demonstrates the very behavior of terrorist, but on the grandest scale 
imaginable, outside the flood story told in Genesis. Apart from the Exodus 
story making a virtue out of terrorism, the story also seems to endorse a 
racist view of the world. The Egyptian empire, like most empires, 
subjugated more than just the Jewish people, but God and Moses only saw fit 
to commit acts of terrorism for the expressed purpose of liberating only a 
small segment of the population, leaving all other oppressed groups to 
wither under the lash of their Egyptian masters, as well as suffer the 
calamities sent by Yahweh. Finally, to add insult to injury, God made the 
Pharaoh incapable of doing the morally correct thing, and setting his 
slaves free, by ensuring that Pharaoh's heart would be "hardened" against 
the idea (Exodus 7:1-6). So God is punishing Pharaoh, through terrorism, 
for a crime that God personally had a hand in sustaining!? Only a person 
brainwashed by religious lunacy could find this story uplifting or 
laudable. ﻿

Balout, L., C. Roubet & C. Desroches-Noblecourt [eds.] (1985) La Momie de 
Ramsès II: Contribution Scientifique à l'Égyptologie (Paris: Editions 
Recherche sur les Civilizations)....
Professor P. F. Ceccaldi, with a research team behind him, studied some 
hairs which were removed from the mummy's scalp. Ramesses II was 90 
years-old when he died, and his hair had turned white. Ceccaldi determined 
that the reddish-yellow colour of the mummy's hair had been brought about 
by its being dyed with a dilute henna solution; it proved to be an example 
of the cosmetic attentions of the embalmers. However, traces of the hair's 
original colour (in youth), remain in the roots, even into advanced old 
age. Microscopic examinations proved that the hair roots contained traces 
of natural red pigments, and that therefore, during his youth, Ramesses II 
had been red-haired. It was concluded that these red pigments did not 
result from the hair somehow fading, or otherwise altering post-mortem, but 
did indeed represent Ramesses' natural hair colour. Ceccaldi also studied a 
cross-section of the hairs, and he determined from their oval shape, that 
Ramesses had been "cymotrich" (wavy-haired). Finally, he stated that such a 
combination of features showed that Ramesses had been a "leucoderm" 
(white-skinned person). [Balout, et al. (1985) 254-257.]

Great review discussion!
Please pardon my focusing in on one topic here, but I for one did indeed 
enjoy Ridley Scott's film Kingdom of Heaven (It is actually one of my all 
time favorite films). As with anyone, this is simply a matter of my humble 
opinion and taste, although, with regard to the subject of racial "white 
washing" being brought up in this review, it is a subject of note that 
Kingdom of Heaven (per example) was an extremely diverse film where 
ethnicity is concerned, and did a wonderful job of balancing mixed race 
with fantastic talent (Ghassan Massoud as a prime example).

That said, and despite my being admittedly partial to Ridley Scott's 
craftsmanship, I totally agree that no director is without fault, and every 
Hollywood film, sadly, seems forced to endure it's dose of racial 
translation.
Many common film stereotypes, be them a matter of race or accent (as you so 
keenly noted with the overuse of British accents throughout film history) 
are a double-sided concern in my opinion. Where I certainly applaud the 
greater levels of authenticity that modern film has begun to (successfully) 
expose audiences too, I also would mention that film is an artistic medium, 
and thus not always to be judged based upon documentary standard fact. Even 
where historical portrayals are concerned, the medium is simply going to be 
created through the artistic, as well as creative lens of the artists 
behind it's production, and additionally accepted, or rejected, by the 
viewing audiences desire to be entertained and or educated.

I'll stop blabbing and simply state that hopefully, where the topic of 
casting is concerned (i.e. Sigourney Weaver, etc.), we will be rewarded by 
the director's intent behind the casting choices once we are able to enjoy 
this entire film in theaters.

Cheers, and thanks for this wonderful review!﻿

Where is this insistence on the black/white dichotomy coming from? Every 
issue and race and culture and second of human history doesn't come down to 
whether people are white or black. Take a look at people in India. Some of 
those people are MUCH darker than Idris Elba, but they're not "Black", 
while many Africans are just as dark, but have different hair. West 
Africans are more typified by broader noses, while Ethiopians and north 
Africans are typified by thinner lips and sharper features. Of course, your 
mileage may vary, people say I have a Jewish nose, but I haven't a drop of 
Jewish blood in me (that I know of). People from Papa New Guinea have dark 
skin like African black people, but they also tend to be very short have 
have strong chins and a very distinct pattern of features unique to their 
own historical tribes.

Based on the decent amount of Egyptian art I've digested over the years, 
and taking into consideration their demonstration of diversity and range of 
skin tone and the delicacy of their depicted (if exaggerated) features, it 
is my opinion, that Egyptians were olive to brown skinned, but hardly ever 
got as dark as Nubians (which is why they depicted Ethiopians Kushites and 
Nubians differently than they did themselves, with tight shorter hair and 
sashes across their chests, and skin so dark they literally used black 
paint). However, they depicted heir neighbors to the east and north as 
being considerably lighter in skin tone. Interestingly, Semites and 
ESPECIALLY Lebanese were both shown with much lighter skin, almost like a 
Greek person. 

In short, I think they might have looked a bit like a Southern Indian from 
Calcutta might today, but with shaved head, heavy make-up, and braided wigs 
that gave them a Dreadlocked look (actual hair texture is irrelevant since 
they tended to shave it off).

Of course people migrate, and of course the dynasties changed over the 
years. One dynasty was historically thought to be from the South and was 
likely black as we consider Nubians to have been, while most rulers post 
Alexander the Great were likely very light skinned (though I'd say they 
likely weren't pale).

be great if the performers cast were of the same race as the character

could be wrong, but I think that foreign films can be equally as guilty 
when it comes to (their own version of) "whitewashing." That being said, I 
do think that Sigourney Weaver looks a bit out of place; she was probably 
cast due to her previous working relationship with Ridley Scott.﻿

when a character is onscreen, rather than the quality of the work being 
done. Sure, there are some instances where a certain type of person is 
required, i.e., a biopic. However, in this case the story of the Exodus is 
fairly universal at this point, and of questionable historicity to boot.

trailer review, the story of Moses and the Exodus doesn't have that 
cultural specificity anymore because of the spread of Christianity, even if 
it would mean more to Jews. Furthermore, Ridley Scott is entitled to work 
with who he chooses, to fulfill his (and the screenwriter's) vision. That 
doesn't mean he's immune to criticism of his choices, but it is his 
prerogative to make them. And as an established director, I'd be more apt 
to trust the decisions he makes.
